reviewText: The problem with this 2008 low scale, low budget film is it is filled with stereotyped well-known TV actors.  When TV actors are so profound, famous or infamous, we cannot see them playing anything but those characters.  So, immediately they are not cast well for the film.  Everybody loves Raymond's mom, Doris Roberts is a love interest of Grandfather Joe played by Andy Griffith.  Opie's real brother Clint Howard and his father Lance Howard appear.  Also, another character Geoffrey Owens from Cosby show appears.It's sad to see that our beloved Andy Griffith has aged, but more shocking is that he plays the character of a senior man who soon discovers that his sexual virility is raised with the enhancement of Viagra, (unbeknown) to him at the time.  Then, he is in bed with another senior, played by Seinfeld's mom, Liz Sheridan.  And it is clear that he gets a b*job, loves it, and talks about it, especially when he said "she took off her dentures" !!The premise of this film is finding love.  A young man, David teaches his grandfather  Joe, how to get the women while  he, (David) is trying his hand at it too.  Grandfather Joe lost his wife two years prior and is feeling lonely in the nursing home, can't get it up anymore until things change.The romantic comedy is amusing, simple and with many sexual references.  Sheriff Andy Taylor in bed with a woman, Seinfeld's mom??  Who woulda thunk?  The movie is nowhere near hilarious, amusing, but not hilarious.....Rizzo
summary: Sheriff Andy Taylor gets a B*job from Seinfeld's mom!!

reviewText: In this age when there are so many movies that have violence, horror and just plain filth, this one is a step above.  It does contain some sexual content, but in a funny way, and there is no nudity.  It has a great cast of characters that show how life and love are always something that we all strive for yet if you are a player, it doesn't always get you what you want.  We watched this with my family and we were all laughing.  it's a great movie to watch if you just need a pick me up.

reviewText: I don't write a lot of reviews, but with the passing of Andy Griffith I felt it was time.  So Grandpa "Andy Griffith" is a little horny and has his cap set for another retiree "Doris Roberts".  Clint Howard is the ruthless car salesman, who does not care a thing about Grandpa.  This movie is about one of the cutest I have seen in a while. it tells a little story about Grandpa & his adult grandson and how they both would like to get their woman.Grandpa becomes the Casanova of the retirement home and has his way with women and the other man played by "Rance Howard" is not ready to give up his girl yet.  This is a light hearted  comedy that will make you smile.  It is no way a small children family movie, but would be appreciated by parents & adult children.

reviewText: One thing I must say about this hilarious comedy is it feels like something the late John Hughes might have made. Only without silly teens in high school. It didn't look like such an enjoyable film from the teaser-trailers--but boy, did I love this movie. Also...don't confuse this with the four or five others that share the same title. This is a 2008 offering and miraculously, there was no other film by the same title released that year or since then.David Mitchell (a strangely effeminate Paul Campbell) is a raging 'player', an almost sexually incontinent ladies' man. With essentially little life outside his dad's (hilarious Clint Howard) car dealership, what has he got to lose chasing the babes? Except that David's Grandpa Joe (Andy Griffith) won't forgive him for taking the job and sticking grandpa in a super-fine condominium.This is a lapse that makes no sense in the story...but David visits his Grandpa Joe, who is despondent and threatens suicide because he's a widower. David offers to teach Grandpa Joe "rules of the game". What ensues is hilarious, though thoughtful, comedy with David trying to get his grandfather a girlfriend. First at the bar, then in a preciously side-splitting scene at the gym. Meanwhile David is tackling his first true love with Julie (a charming Marla Sokoloff).The tale has an incredible turn that I won't spoil--but it is so fun to see David and his grandfather gradually changing into one another, David absorbing his grandpa's wisdom and grandpa becoming a bit of a rake. The woman of grandpa's dreams, Rose (legendary Doris Roberts) happens to be Julie's granddaughter. What each man will learn here will astonish you, though portions of this happy and truly fun movie are predictable. In actuality, I haven't seen a script as funny, moving and original as this, for a long time.What I don't get is the cold shoulder Andy Griffith always gets. He's done a few hilarious bit parts in the past, but this film centers on him. One might say he's actually the romantic lead in this film--and he gives Betty White a run for her money for her widely hyped, great performance in THE PROPOSAL. I'm getting tired of Andy Griffith's talents being treated like a video ghost.Well, the studio's behind him: the website offers a "dancing grandpa", featuring Andy Griffith busting some pretty good moves for a guy in his mid-80s. (He's just a couple years younger than Betty White, but Griffith does show his age a lot more.) The dancing Griffith is featured during the credits and it is a hoot and a half!This film may not merit instant classic classification, and you may not want to have it in your video collection...but watch it. You won't regret a moment of it and you may even deem it a classic.

reviewText: Play the Gameis like a double romantic comedy, with a grandfather and grandson going after a grandmother and granddaughter at the same time. However, unlike most romantic comedies, the girls aren't desperate romantics, but rather one up the guys at the love game. All of the actors are wonderful. Andy Griffith is absolutely charming as the "player" grandfather. The ending has a twist worthy of M. Night Shyamalan. Just a brief warning: there is a lot of talk about sex and scenes insinuating it, especially between the elderly, which can get kind of nasty. It's funny, but sometimes goes a bit too far.

reviewText: I wasted one hour of my life before I bailed on this film.  Though billed as a comedy, it failed miserably for multiple reasons.  All these actors should be embarrassed for taking money for this trash.First of all, it is supposed to be a romantic comedy but in many ways, you've watched this movie dozens of time, as the script was unoriginal and there were no laugh out loud moments.  It's main premise is that by being more manipulative than the prey (females), allows the male (real men (respectful, honest and emotionally mature) would not do this) to have complete control in the relationship.  Control should be gained through any means necessary, which includes whatever deceptive means on the person targeted.Paul Campbell plays a playboy. He works as a successful car salesman, and he consistently manages  to exceed other sales people in profitability on car sales at the dealership.  How, because he lies the best!  He teaches his Grandpa (Andy Griffith) to find a girlfriend after not dating for 60 years.  Although, Griffith is successful by applying some of these techniques.  He is ultimately tricked when the woman, who likes him and is very direct about her sexual desires slips him a Viagra in his alcoholic drink (great teach children that it's okay to lie and drug unsuspecting people - what if Grandpa had a heart condition?)!  Of course, they are soon in bed doing the "deed", when this woman does some "new" things on Grandpa -I stopped the DVD. Meanwhile, Paul is having a much more difficult time in conquering his newest target using his "tricks", because she is more adept at using the same techniques on him without his realization.So, the joke is apparently on the men, who manage to be "outplayed" by the women in deceiving.  How flattering to women...not.This movie mocks honesty and true love in nearly every scene.  Its key plot (messages), is do whatever you want to get what you want, this is the premise of Humanism.  Each character is operating according to these principles.  Paul's best-friend, Omar is a fellow car sales man, spends his evenings operating as Campbell's wing man, although he is married and lying to his wife stating he is playing poker, when he is cruising bars with Paul.  Omar's wife traps him repeatedly in this lie, he has no consequences and he talks about how dull marriage is.  Gee, marriage which has been practiced for millenniums by many cultures is so old fashioned, its "boring".  I guess being single isn't lonely if you are always pursuing the next target, er, I mean person...It's true "Art imitates life" in business and the dating world.  Perhaps, this kind of thinking, which started gaining acceptance in the 1980's, it is most likely why more than 1/2 of American marriages end in divorce.  Serial monogamy is now becoming the norm, instead of the rarity it once was.  People now give priority to their wants over those of their partner's, co-workers, children and family members.  Though many call this being fulfilled or achieving goals, at the root, it is completely selfish and self-centered. It may be the reason, so many people, both single and married can't find a positive relationship.  Many discover after marrying or investing years into another person, that neither are who the other one thought, because one or both fail portray themselves realistically; as reflected in comments such as "she isn't the girl I married" this disappointment and disillusionment in romantic relationships becomes a pattern.If you find lying and selfishness funny, then don't just rent it, buy it!However, if you want to have your children fulfilling personal and career relationships, skip this movie that salutes selfishness, lying and manipulation as a means to an end; that  controlling others by deception despite the impact on another's emotional health is not your responsibility.The only positive I can say is that I checked it out of the library, so all I'm out of my time watching and writing this review.
summary: A Big Fat Raspberry to Golden Rule

reviewText: This movie Play the Game is about a young man named David Mitchell who is very close to his grandfater, Joe (Andy Griffith). All of the sudden Joe admits to David that he is lonely and wants a woman to be his companion.  David shows Joe how to play the game of dating.  While David is showing Joe the ropes of dating he meets a girl named Julie Larabee (Marla Sokoff). David meets Julie playing Football in the park.David is crazy about Juile. He tries to go wherever she goes.  Eventally Joe becomes BIG MAN IN THE RETIREMENT CENTER. The first woman Joe meets is Edna (Liz Sheridan).  Edna and Joe get along very well. The next woman joe meets is Rose Sherman(Doris Roberts). Watch this movie to see what happened to Joe and Edna. Also find out if David, Julie, Rose and Joe ever gets together.  If you were a Andy Griffith fan this was his last movie he did. Enjoy!

reviewText: David (Paul Campbell) is a very successful car salesman, and considers himself a regular Don Juan.  But he's also got a sensitive side, and that revolves around his grandfather, Joe (Andy Griffith), who lives in a retirement community and pines for his departed wife.  As David begins his game plan for a new conquest (which is how he looks at it), he takes a the role as teacher for Joe, who is looking for companionship, nothing more.The story gets complicated, as David becomes less successful at pursuing a particular woman, while Joe becomes wildly successful as he experiences the pleasures of sex ("She even took her dentures out!").At the movie's conclusion, and this is unexpected, the storyline gets even MORE complicated!I'm usually irked by these "Women are so predictable and I have what they want" themes, but since this one puts David in his place, I forgive the director of Play The Game.  And Andy Griffith is the cutest dirty old man!  There's a scene with his pants belted about a foot above his waist, rocking on his heels, and tapping his toes to the music... he could be back in Mayberry!  But he's such an articulate and emotional actor.  It's fun to watch his evolution in this movie.
summary: Andy Griffith is the cutest dirty old man!
